title: Why did Riot give morde more complexity,too much counterplay,polarized gameplay,and call it healthy?
body:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IKe_IMl92sg

(some of) my thoughts on the matter cover :25 - :45 seconds

here's some context: I was a huge fan of the old morde kit (pre-rework), and I loved how simple it was. I mained it for half of season 4 and from the start of season 5 to now. I have played 830 games of old mordekaiser from when the new match history was launched (for however that goes back).

No matter how much people bitch and moan about how morde was before, he had been played with and against for so long people could deal with his powerspikes very well. Pre-rework, Morde sat at around 50-51% winrate across all elos. He obviously had his strengths, but wasn't so powerful to just outright win every game he ever played. He had a niche, and while he didn't have the playrate that thresh, vayne, or leona have, he had his loyal mains who played him, as well as people who played him whenever he had a very favorable matchup.

Fast forward to now, and we have the current mess. Mordekaiser, who used to be simple, straightforward, and a champion based almost entirely on positioning instead of making immensely flashy plays, is now a champion with a lot more gimmicks, more arbitrary complexity, ramp up time on the one ability that most of his power budget is invested in, and less options in solo laning altogether. 

Why?

Why does he need to be such a drastically different champion than he was before? 

What makes altering his Q, a strong ability in its own rights, into a ramp up? Morde's old Q was a solid ability in a solo lane, and it could be maxed first in a top lane environment quite comfortably. It gave him a source of good damage that could be accessed instantly and punish a player for being isolated from their minion wave if they chose to fight Morde. It wasn't an instagib level of damage (although it could be built that way with lichbane), but it was certainly enough to make opponents think twice about cockily walking up to him. 

Side note: Morde was a champ that punished or rewarded positioning. That alone was something that held him back from just dominating everything. If he got caught out during a bad extension and the opposing laner was someone who could dish out consistent damage to him while CCing him (a lot of champs can do this relatively easily), Morde was dead.

What makes altering his W, a strong ability in its own rights, into an ability locked only for botlane morde who has a support? Morde's W before the rework was a perfectly fine ability, and gave him some strong situational mobility in a solo lane. It was strong enough to possibly max first (this was seen in an LCS game where morde was played in), but overall was strong enough with one point in it to save morde's life every now and then.

What makes altering his E, again, a strong ability in its own rights, into a shadow of its former self? On a champ that absolutely needs waveclear due to lacking mobility and CC? And keeping the health costs the same? Why on earth should anyone max E until last now? The health costs are large for an early max, and morde doesn't build spellvamp anymore.

Why does morde's ult become unavailable when a dragon ghost is captured? A dragon ghost that is mostly ignorable during teamfights that aren't over the first dragon and only makes morde situationally strong? Morde's ult used to be a simple DoT and the rest of his kit was strong enough that it didn't need to have such a situational gimmick attached to it. If morde's team is strong enough to take dragon and get that dragon ghost, then they were probably going to get a tower off of that anyway. Even if not, why does the rest of morde's kit have to be balanced around it? The dragon ghost is purely a "win more" mechanic, nothing more. 

How is being situationally powerful, with the requirements of needing a support and getting the dragon ghost, healthy gameplay?

How is being even stronger against melee champs, while being even weaker against ranged champions that can kite, healthy gameplay?

Before the rework, while morde did have bad matchups, he had options to deal with those matchups. There were a few matchups he would win outright, a lot of matchups that were skill based, and some matchups he lost very hard. Such is the way with all champions in this game. How is that considered unhealthy, when all champions are subject to that? Were Morde matchups only considered in a vacuum, where the only factors were Morde and his lane opponent? The inherent problem with that is that morde pushed waves naturally, so he would leave himself vulnerable to ganks, which, newsflash, happens all the time in every match ever. That is one of the biggest weaknesses old morde had.

**So, to wrap up, a simple champion with clear strengths and weaknesses is subject to unnecessary change and alienates an entire group of players who were mains of a champion, all for the sake of making him situationally stronger, and giving him "win more" mechanics instead of sticking to a simple, strong brawler?**

I'm sorry, but just because morde can be situationally strong, does not make him a strong champion overall.

That depends, how stupid is your lane opponent? Oh fuck, he's decent? What champion is he playing? Oh shit, he's not playing Morde, too? Chances are he's got CC, or Mobility. Or both. Good thing you're a champion who's only threatening when you can get to that third stri- oh wait YOU CAN'T. Uhg...fuck CertainlyT...just fuck him...why did solo-lane Morde have to die for his stupid experimental concept?

The thing that I find really messed up though, is that the new "power-loaded" third strike of Q is not that much stronger than the old Q. The Q damage splits his hit into both physical and magical compared to Old Morde's Q of converting the entire hit into magical damage. This means that due to the way damage negation works part of his Q gets reduced by armor and the rest gets reduced by magic resist. So in order for the full damage to go through, a Morde would need to build both non-negligible amounts of armor and magic penentration.  Now if a player decides to not "care" about the physical part of Morde's Q, his third strike is essentially at the same power level as the Multi-hit portion of Mordekaiser's old Q!

TLDR: CertainlyT essentially took the mulit-hit portion of Mordekaiser's old Q and converted into a single-target power strike. For this "change," Mordekaiser's kit took various nerfs in order to "balance" him out. This re-work was very creative indeed. /s

OP, do you know what's the difference between Riot and lets say... you?

You've played pre-reworked Morde 830~times more than all Rioters combined.

The worst part of this rework is how all Morde's power is stored within his Q ability. Like, Morde now is a guy with AOE shield that needs ally to be used, completely useless poke ability and completely broken melee ability. The whole philosophy of Morde now is to hit 3rd Q - that's Morde in nutshell, his Q. Before, he was quite complicated champ. While his abilities where very simple, he had to worry about a lot of things: you had to use your abilities intelligently, manage to poke your enemy and maintain your shield while not pushing the lane too much (so you don't get ganked). There was a lot of depth - good positioning, warding, even some predictioning, like is your opponent going to facecheck that brush you are waiting in to burst someone? For me,it was one of the funniest part of old Morde: walking into some brush, and then, just wait: is he gonna enter it? Come any close to it? Ok, he entered my brush, let's do this : R-Q-E. And even when Morde was ahead, he could be shut down, because he was squishy and burstable when he didn't have his shield charged. Right now, his abilities are complicated, but his whole playstyle revolves only around his 3rd Q. You don't have to worry about lane being pushed too much. When somebody engages you, just activate your Q and smack them... The whole rework took the essence of Morde while making his kit (ekhem, I mean, his Q) super punishing against poorly positioned enemies. Also, if his ahead, he's gonna wreck everybody and win game, because he basically needs only 2 damaging items to kill somebody, then he just builds tank so it's super hard to kill him. It's kinda a shame that this rework took such a direction. I expected something better :/

i dont know if i can really comment on sion before his rework too much, because i played only a few games of his old kit, but from what I did play of it, it was kind of a mess, with half of his kit being almost entirely useless under a certain buildpath

but even so, he (new sion) has a kit that is strong overall, and has different strategies behind it, and the best part is it doesn't have all of its power budget locked away in a single ability, and it certainly isn't loaded with situational gimmicks that only apply if x and y happen. use Q to slow/knockup, w is a shield, e is ranged harass, R is initiate ult. simple, yet effective!

new morde is a far different beast than his former form.

old morde Q: empowered auto that echoed to 3 enemies and did equal damage to the target and the enemies, with some bonus damage if isolated.
new morde Q: 3 empowered autos on a champion that has nerfed attack speed. the first two are needed to have been struck to realize its full potential. on a champ that doesn't really have room to itemize attack speed beyond trinity force, why can i reasonably expect to hit all 3 in a situation? where is the option for a middle ground auto that does damage along the lines of the second empowered Q instantly instead? a situationally powerful ability is not an ability that is overall strong, imo. **if I have to have a support with me to access the full power of it, it is not an ability that I can consider strong.**

old morde W: extra MR and Armor, gave around a sunfire cape's worth of damage over time for a few seconds, also had some situational mobility, could be cast on minions or just cast on self if nothing else is around.
new morde W: situational cast that requires an ally around to benefit from it at all. if no allies are present, it is entirely useless to have at all.

old morde E: damage in a cone, strong bases allowed a max, but punished spamming with health costs until spellvamp was purchased
new morde E: damage in a cone, weaker bases but an AD ratio encourages building morde in a hybrid manner. health costs remain the same, damage overall is lower.

old morde R: DoT that when enemies died under, turned them into an AA based minion that did damage based on the items the champion had
new morde R: same as above, but with the added situational dragon ghost. again, situationally strong (ie an ability that you have no direct access to without extraneous circumstances isn't an ability you can consider strong in a situation where you need damage/CC/mobility right away)

my point is I don't think it is healthy to pin so much situational power onto a champion that used to be all about that direct, up front damage. sion before his rework had abilities that were similar to what they are now, and altering them into what they are now made him a stronger champion

morde's changes make him less coherent and direct as a champion, and i think he suffers for it overall

*cough*  Um... heh. I'e played as/with the new Mordekaiser and so far, he seems okay. I mean, sure his power has shifted to situationally rather than all around and his early game has turned into basically a complete train wreck if you die once, but I still think he's fine. Yeah he needs number tweaks, and some buffs/nerfs to his abilities, but that'll happen longer down the road. Not to be COMPLETELY defeatist here, but writing an overly long and complicated essay on why Mordekaiser was in an okay spot before, but thanks to an over indulged rework he has turned into the situational monster rather than an okay all-rounder won't really solve anything. Riot made a rework. They teased it, talked about it, and released it. And it won't change. Numbers, sure. But Mordekaiser will (at least for the time being) be stuck in the spot that he is in now with his new found abilities. You might as well try and adapt to the changing environment, instead of standing stubborn while the tidal wave of change smashes over you. A fool will stand and fight a battle he cannot win. But a smart man will instead, go along with the things that are happening, and will live to fight another day.
Sorry if I gave an opinion here, but I will gracefully accept those downvotes you will inevitably bestow upon me.
